title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the required reserve ratio as 10% and/or does not show the work.

Required Reserve Ratio= Required Reserves Demand Deposits = $120,000 $1,200,000 =10% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7DA2@

The response calculates the required reserve ratio as 10% and shows the work.

Required Reserve Ratio= Required Reserves Demand Deposits = $120,000 $1,200,000 =10% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7DA2@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the monetary base will increase by $80,000 and/or does not explain that the central bank bond purchase increases reserves by $80,000 and the monetary base is the sum of reserves and currency in circulation.

The response states that the monetary base will increase by $80,000 and explains that the central bank bond purchase increases reserves by $80,000 and the monetary base is the sum of reserves and currency in circulation.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the maximum change in the money supply as an increase of $800,000 and/or does not show the work.

Maximum Change in the Money Supply=$80,000× 1 0.1 =$800,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6B63@

The response calculates the maximum change in the money supply as an increase of $800,000 and shows the work.

Maximum Change in the Money Supply=$80,000× 1 0.1 =$800,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6B63@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the velocity of money as 3 and/or does not show the work.

Velocity of Money= Change in Nominal GDP Change in the Money Supply = $2,400,000 $800,000 =3 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@88E3@

The response calculates the velocity of money as 3 and shows the work.

Velocity of Money= Change in Nominal GDP Change in the Money Supply = $2,400,000 $800,000 =3 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@88E3@

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that real output will increase in the short run and/or does not explain that the increase in the money supply will decrease the nominal interest rate, which will increase interest-sensitive spending and increase aggregate demand.

The response states that real output will increase in the short run and explains that the increase in the money supply will decrease the nominal interest rate, which will increase interest-sensitive spending and increase aggregate demand.
